title: Add path-based HTTP API endpoints
Evaluate whether NodeRegistry is still needed after HTTP/store split
MCP server for firing commands to commonplace paths
description: An MCP server that exposes commonplace document paths as callable tools. MCP clients can invoke commands on commonplace documents, bridging LLM tool-use with the commonplace reactive document system.

title: Sync tool should checkout directory JSON definition as .json file
description: The sync tool (commonplace-sync) should write the JSON definition of a directory as a file named `.json` in that directory. This would allow users to see and potentially edit the directory's metadata/structure definition alongside the directory contents.

title: One-time scheduled events (at-style)
description:
Schedule events to fire at a specific point in the future. Unlike cron (recurring), these are one-shot:
- Reminders
- Delayed actions
- Future-dated triggers
- Timeout/deadline events

Could share infrastructure with cron scheduling but with single-fire semantics.

title: Support JSON files as Yjs map/array types in directory sync
description:
Summary: Allow synced JSON files to be stored as Yjs map/array types (not plain text) so JSON structure is preserved in CRDT.

Files to modify:
- src/document.rs (content type handling / default doc type)
- src/diff.rs (JSON diff generation if needed)
- src/bin/sync.rs (JSON file handling, initial sync)
- src/sync/content_type.rs (content type mapping, potentially new metadata)
- docs/FILESYSTEM.md (clarify JSON type behavior)
- docs/WIRING_DIAGRAM_FILES.md (if wiring files need special handling)

Implementation steps:
1. Identify how JSON documents are represented in yrs (map/array) vs text and how current commits are applied.
2. Decide on encoding for JSON files in sync (map vs array based on top-level JSON).
3. Update sync upload/replace logic to send JSON updates rather than text edits for JSON files.
4. Ensure server-side content retrieval returns serialized JSON for map/array docs.
5. Add tests/fixtures for JSON map/array round-trips through sync.

Example:
- Before: file data.json stored as plain text in Yjs text.
- After: data.json stored as Yjs map or array (based on top-level JSON), serialized to JSON text on read/write.

title: External process MQTT client as first-class citizen
description:
Allow a separate Unix process to connect to MQTT and perform all the same actions as the JS sandbox evaluator:
- Subscribe to document commits
- Create/own output documents
- Receive commands on owned document paths
- Emit events as owned documents

This makes external processes (any language) first-class participants in the commonplace reactive graph, using MQTT as the protocol.

title: Fix server replay to use node's content type for JSON documents
description:
P1 from PR #6 review: The server's /nodes/:id/head and replace endpoints replay with ContentType::Text, but Y.Map commits need ContentType::Json. When replaying Y.Map commits with Text type, replay.rs returns "Text root not found" causing 500 errors.

Fix: Update src/api.rs (around lines 460-464) to use the node's actual content type when replaying commits.

title: Add integration tests for MQTT path resolution
Macaroons for MQTT-layer authorization
description:
Implement macaroon-based authorization enforced at the MQTT layer. Macaroons provide:
- Delegatable, attenuatable credentials
- Fine-grained path-based permissions
- Caveat-based restrictions (time, scope, etc.)

Enforcement at MQTT means all clients (JS sandbox, external processes, CLI, MCP servers) go through the same auth layer.

title: Fix sync race condition: upload_task sends stale content during B->A sync
description:
When a server edit arrives via SSE, the handle_server_edit function fetches HEAD and writes to the local file. However, the file watcher can trigger upload_task with stale file content before the write completes, causing the old content to be synced back to the server.

Root cause: Echo detection relies on comparing file content to last_written_content, but there's a window between SSE notification and file write where upload_task can read stale content.

Possible fixes:
1. Add a flag to pause upload_task during server writes
2. Use file modification timestamp comparison
3. Add sequence numbers to track edit origin

title: Telegram messages ↔ file integration
description:
Bidirectional sync between Telegram messages and commonplace documents:
- Receive Telegram messages as document updates or events
- Send document content/edits to Telegram chats
- Subscribe to specific chats/channels
- Bot or user account authentication

Enables messaging-as-document patterns and chat automation.

title: Represent directory trees as Yjs JSON (Y.Map) instead of text JSON
description:
Currently, the fs-root document uses TEXT content type with JSON stored as a text string. This was a workaround because the edit system (diff.rs, replay.rs) uses TEXT-based Yjs updates (Y.Text), but DocumentNode for JSON type uses Y.Map internally.

The proper solution would be to use native Yjs JSON structure (Y.Map) for directory schemas, which would enable:
- Proper CRDT merging of concurrent schema changes
- More efficient updates (only changed entries, not full document replacement)
- Better conflict resolution for concurrent file additions/deletions

title: Move HTTP interface to separate binary with MQTT connection
description: Extract the HTTP interface into a new binary that connects to the document store over MQTT instead of direct access.

title: Enforce mandatory file extensions in filesystem sync
description: Update commonplace filesystem so that file extensions are mandatory. Only .json, .txt, .xml, .xhtml, and .bin files can be synced, and they must correspond to their Yjs implementations.

title: Convert sync client to use path-based API
Handle rename events so new paths get sync tasks
description:
notify reports renames as `Modify(Name)` events; the current mapping treats all `is_modify()` as `DirEvent::Modified`. The modified handler only re-pushes schema and never starts new per-file sync tasks or removes old ones, so a rename leaves the new file untracked and the old path's tasks running until restart.

Consider handling rename explicitly (or treating `Modify(Name)` as delete+create).

title: Implement Router Documents (docs/ROUTER.md)
description:
Implement the router document feature as specified in docs/ROUTER.md:

- Add `--router <node-id>` CLI flag (repeatable)
- Router documents are JSON with `version`, `nodes`, and `edges` 
- Server subscribes to router document blue port for changes
- Apply/diff wiring based on router document content
- Emit `router.error` events on red port for errors
- Handle node creation hints from `nodes` section
- Track router-created wires separately from other wires

title: Sandboxed JS evaluator with document subscriptions and output
description:
Run a JS file in a sandbox with the ability to:
- Declare dependencies on other commonplace documents
- Subscribe to commits on those dependencies
- Create a read-only output document
- Listen for commands on the output document's path
- Emit events as that document

The JS file acts as a reactive transform: inputs → computation → output document.

title: Cron-style recurring scheduled events
description:
Fire events on a recurring schedule (like crontab). Use cases:
- Periodic document refresh triggers
- Scheduled backup/export jobs
- Regular polling of external sources
- Time-based workflow triggers

Could be defined as a special node type or as a configuration on documents.

title: Identify and refactor large files into smaller modules
description: Audit the codebase for files that have grown too large and could benefit from being split into smaller, more focused modules. Look for files with multiple distinct responsibilities that could be separated.

title: Fix P1: Use JSON replay when pushing Y.Map schema updates (PR #6)
description: From PR #6 Codex review: The change switches the initial fs-root schema write to a Y.Map update but needs to use JSON replay instead for proper handling.

title: tmux ↔ file integration
description:
Bidirectional sync between tmux pane content and commonplace documents:
- Capture tmux pane content to a document (scrollback, current view)
- Send content from a document to a tmux pane (sendkeys)
- Subscribe to pane output as a stream
- Control tmux sessions/windows/panes via document commands

Enables terminal-as-document patterns and terminal automation.

description: An MCP server that reads a specified commonplace JSON document and exposes its contents as MCP tools, resources, and prompts. The JSON document defines the MCP schema, and the server dynamically serves those definitions to MCP clients.

description: A command-line tool that sends commands to a specified commonplace document path. Allows scripting and manual interaction with commonplace documents via their red port (events/commands).

title: Fix P1: Preserve schema deletions when pushing updates (PR #7)
description: From PR #7 Codex review: When pushing schema updates, deletions are not being preserved. The code always posts an edit built by create_yjs_map_update but this may not handle entry deletions properly. Need to investigate and fix.

title: Fix P2: Skip wiring when an identical edge already exists (PR #8)
description: From PR #8 Codex review: The router creates wires based on managed_wires, but if a wiring already exists from an external source (e.g., /nodes/:from/wire/:to), this code will still call wire_* and create a second subscription. Consider checking existing registry wirings before adding.

title: TypeScript support for sandboxed evaluator
description:
Extend the JS sandbox evaluator to support TypeScript. This could mean:
- Transpiling TS → JS before evaluation
- Supporting .ts file extensions in sandbox
- Type definitions for the sandbox API (dependencies, output documents, events)

This makes the sandbox more ergonomic for larger/complex reactive transforms.

title: Fix P1: Respect explicit node_id from server schema (PR #4)
description: From PR #4 Codex review: When the server's FsSchema uses DocEntry.node_id for stable IDs, this should be respected instead of deriving IDs.
